title: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of POTS in adolescents and adults. Includes diagnostic criteria, autonomic testing, subtype classification (hyperadrenergic, neuropathic, hypovolemic/deconditioning), and pharmacologic/non-pharmacologic treatment. Covers ED presentation for acute decompensation, inpatient management, and outpatient chronic management. Excludes other causes of orthostatic intolerance unless part of differential.

Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal Hgb (>12 g/dL F, >13 g/dL M); no leukocytosis

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities causing tachycardia; dehydration; renal function
Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal Na, K, Mg, glucose, creatinine

Core Labs (All Patients).target: HR rise <30 bpm; no SBP drop >=20 mmHg

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude cardiac arrhythmia, structural disease, pre-excitation, long QT
Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal sinus rhythm; normal intervals; sinus tachycardia expected upright

Pregnancy as cause of hemodynamic changes

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Volume expansion; first-line for hypovolemic/general POTS

dosing.instructions: Start 0.05-0.1 mg daily; titrate by 0.05 mg q1-2 weeks; max 0.2 mg daily; takes 1-2 weeks for full effect

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: K+ q2-4 weeks during titration then q3-6 months; supine BP; weight; edema; headache

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Peripheral vasoconstriction; orthostatic symptoms refractory to non-pharmacologic measures

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5 mg TID (upon waking, midday, mid-afternoon); titrate by 2.5 mg q1 week; max 10 mg TID; last dose >=4 hours before bedtime

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Supine hypertension (SBP >180); urinary retention; pheochromocytoma; severe cardiac disease; thyrotoxicosis
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Supine BP (avoid >160/90); urinary symptoms; piloerection (scalp tingling); HR

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Heart rate control; hyperadrenergic symptoms (palpitations, tremor, anxiety)

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg BID-TID; titrate slowly; max 20 mg TID; low doses preferred in POTS (high doses worsen fatigue/exercise intolerance)

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Asthma; severe bradycardia; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; decompensated HF; severe hypotension
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: HR (target standing HR <100, avoid resting <60); BP; fatigue; exercise tolerance

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Heart rate reduction without BP lowering; POTS with inappropriate sinus tachycardia; beta-blocker intolerant

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5 mg BID with meals; titrate by 2.5 mg q2 weeks; max 7.5 mg BID; selective If-channel blocker

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; sick sinus syndrome (without pacemaker); SA block; 3rd degree AV block; resting HR <60 bpm; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: HR (target resting 60-80); visual phenomena (phosphenes); BP; atrial fibrillation

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Augment ganglionic neurotransmission; milder POTS; avoid BP effects

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg TID; may increase to 60 mg TID; enhances autonomic ganglionic transmission without significant supine hypertension

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Mechanical bowel or urinary obstruction; bradycardia; asthma (relative)

Referrals & Consults.item: Autonomic disorders specialist/neurologist for formal autonomic testing (tilt table, QSART, Valsalva), subtype classification, and chronic management guidance
Cardiology consultation to exclude structural heart disease, arrhythmia, or inappropriate sinus tachycardia as alternative diagnosis
Physical therapy/exercise physiology referral for structured graduated exercise program (Levine or CHOP protocol) tailored to POTS patients starting with recumbent exercise
Rheumatology if joint hypermobility spectrum disorder or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome suspected, given high comorbidity with POTS
Allergy/Immunology if mast cell activation syndrome suspected (flushing, urticaria, anaphylaxis, elevated tryptase with POTS symptoms)
Gastroenterology if significant GI dysmotility (gastroparesis, nausea, constipation) contributing to dehydration and nutritional compromise
Psychiatry/Psychology for comorbid anxiety, depression, or functional overlay; cognitive behavioral therapy for symptom coping strategies
Sleep medicine referral if comorbid insomnia or sleep-disordered breathing contributing to fatigue and autonomic dysfunction

Patient Instructions.item: Drink at least 2-3 liters of fluid daily including water and electrolyte-containing beverages; rapid bolus of 500 mL water before prolonged standing (acutely raises BP via osmopressor reflex)
Increase dietary sodium to 6-10 grams daily using salt tablets or dietary salt (unless contraindicated by hypertension or heart failure) to expand plasma volume
Wear waist-high compression stockings (30-40 mmHg) during all upright activity; use abdominal binder as alternative or adjunct to reduce splanchnic pooling
Avoid prolonged standing; if standing is required, shift weight, cross legs, and tense muscles to promote venous return
Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing with 1-2 minutes at each position to allow hemodynamic adjustment
Recognize warning symptoms (lightheadedness, tunnel vision, palpitations) and immediately sit or lie down to prevent syncope and injury
Avoid triggers: hot environments, large carbohydrate-heavy meals, alcohol, prolonged hot showers/baths, rapid positional changes
Return to ED if syncopal episode occurs, chest pain develops, new neurological symptoms appear, or symptoms acutely worsen despite home measures

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Begin structured graduated exercise program (Levine/CHOP protocol): start with recumbent exercise 30 min 3-4x/week, progress to upright over 3-6 months; exercise is the single most effective long-term intervention for POTS
Eat small, frequent meals rather than large meals to reduce postprandial blood pooling in the splanchnic circulation
Avoid excessive alcohol which causes vasodilation and worsens orthostatic intolerance
Maintain consistent sleep schedule with 7-9 hours nightly; sleep with head of bed elevated 4-6 inches to reduce nocturnal natriuresis
Avoid medications that worsen POTS: diuretics, vasodilators, tricyclic antidepressants (orthostatic effect), stimulants at high dose; review all medications with prescriber
Use cooling strategies for heat sensitivity: cooling vest, cold water intake, portable fan, avoiding prolonged heat exposure
Obtain medical alert identification for patients with frequent presyncope/syncope to inform first responders of POTS diagnosis
Prioritize mental health self-care: POTS is a chronic condition; pace activities, practice stress management, and engage support groups to improve quality of life

differential.features: Elevated resting HR (>100 bpm) in supine AND upright; not posturally triggered; no orthostatic symptoms
differential.tests: 24-hour Holter showing elevated HR at rest; HR does not normalize when supine

differential.features: SBP drop >=20 mmHg or DBP drop >=10 mmHg within 3 min of standing; HR may rise but BP falls significantly
differential.tests: Active stand test or tilt table showing BP drop meeting OH criteria

differential.features: Episodic hypertension, diaphoresis, headache, tachycardia; not postural-dependent
differential.tests: 24-hour urine catecholamines/metanephrines; plasma free metanephrines; adrenal imaging

differential.features: Resting tachycardia; heat intolerance; weight loss; tremor; not position-dependent
Tachycardia and orthostatic symptoms that resolve with correction; pallor; dyspnea
differential.tests: CBC showing Hgb <10 g/dL; symptoms resolve with transfusion/iron

differential.features: Tachycardia with situational triggers (not postural); chest tightness; hyperventilation; paresthesias
differential.tests: Normal active stand test; symptoms reproduce with hyperventilation but not posture alone

differential.features: Sudden onset tachycardia not related to posture; irregular rhythm; very rapid rates (>150 bpm)
differential.tests: ECG showing non-sinus rhythm; Holter or event recorder capturing arrhythmia

differential.features: Tachycardia and orthostatic symptoms that fully resolve with volume repletion; identifiable cause
differential.tests: History (GI illness, poor intake); labs showing hemoconcentration; resolution with IV fluids

differential.features: Orthostatic hypotension (not just tachycardia); hyperpigmentation; hyponatremia; hyperkalemia; fatigue
differential.tests: AM cortisol <3 mcg/dL; ACTH stimulation test; ACTH level

differential.features: Flushing, urticaria, GI symptoms, tachycardia; may coexist with POTS; episodic
differential.tests: Serum tryptase during episode; 24-hr urine histamine metabolites; prostaglandin D2

differential.features: Joint hypermobility; soft/stretchy skin; easy bruising; frequently comorbid with POTS rather than differential
differential.tests: Beighton score >=5; clinical criteria (2017 EDS classification); genetic testing for vascular type

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication initiation; common offenders: stimulants, decongestants, bronchodilators, thyroid supplements
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; improvement with dose reduction or discontinuation

evidence.recommendation: Diagnostic criteria: HR increment >=30 bpm within 10 min of standing without orthostatic hypotension
Tilt table testing as diagnostic standard for POTS
Graduated exercise training (Levine protocol) improves POTS symptoms and cardiovascular fitness
evidence.source: [Fu Q et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20579544/)

evidence.recommendation: Fludrocortisone for volume expansion in POTS
Midodrine reduces orthostatic tachycardia and improves standing tolerance
Ivabradine reduces heart rate and improves symptoms in POTS
evidence.source: [Taub PR et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33602468/)

evidence.recommendation: Pyridostigmine improves symptoms with minimal supine hypertension
ACC Expert Consensus Statement on POTS and autonomic disorders
Hyperadrenergic subtype classification by standing norepinephrine
Compression garments reduce venous pooling and improve orthostatic tolerance
evidence.source: [Figueroa JJ et al. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25448247/)

evidence.recommendation: Small fiber neuropathy in neuropathic POTS subtype
Salt and fluid intake of 2-3 L/day and 6-10 g Na/day as first-line nonpharmacologic therapy

monitoring.item: Orthostatic vital signs (HR and BP at 1, 3, 5, 10 min standing)
monitoring.action: Optimize volume/salt; adjust medications; reassess subtype
Adjust beta-blocker or ivabradine dose; evaluate for over-treatment if <55 bpm

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q2-4 weeks during fludrocortisone titration; then q3-6 months
monitoring.action: Supplement potassium if <3.5; reduce fludrocortisone dose
Reduce midodrine dose; time last dose >=4 hr before bed; add clonidine qHS if persistent

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; within 1 week of desmopressin initiation; monthly on desmopressin
monitoring.action: Hold desmopressin if Na <135; restrict free water; recheck in 48 hours
Increase salt supplementation; dietary counseling; reassess compliance
Reassess treatment; change medication; evaluate compliance
Modify exercise program; reassess medications; evaluate deconditioning
Adjust fludrocortisone; fluid intake; add diuretic if needed for edema

disposition.criteria: Confirmed POTS exacerbation with HR response to IV fluids; stable orthostatic vitals post-hydration; no syncope in ED; cardiac arrhythmia excluded; tolerating oral fluids; reliable outpatient follow-up arranged
POTS flare requiring IV hydration with incomplete symptom resolution; awaiting initial cardiac workup (ECG, troponin, echo); first-time presentation requiring diagnostic evaluation

Severe decompensation with recurrent presyncope/syncope despite IV fluids; unable to tolerate oral intake; need for telemetry to exclude arrhythmia; new-onset POTS requiring inpatient autonomic workup; comorbid condition requiring inpatient management

Hemodynamic instability not responding to volume resuscitation; sustained HR >150 bpm with concern for arrhythmia; syncope with injury requiring monitoring; concurrent critical illness triggering POTS decompensation
All newly diagnosed POTS: autonomic neurology within 2-4 weeks; established POTS with stable management: q3-6 months; post-medication titration: 2-4 weeks
Medication monitoring q2-4 weeks during titration; stable patients q3-6 months; annual echocardiogram if structural concern; exercise program reassessment q3 months
